questions.question: John had 5/8 of a pizza. He ate 1/4 of what he had. What fraction of the whole pizza did he eat?
Express 7/12 as a fraction with denominator 36
A rope 24m long was cut into 3 pieces. The first piece was 3/8 of the rope, the second was 1/3 of the rope. What fraction of the rope was the third piece?
questions.explanation:
First: 3/8, Second: 1/3 = 8/24
Common denominator 24: 3/8 = 9/24, 1/3 = 8/24
Total of first two: 9/24 + 8/24 = 17/24
Third piece: 1 - 17/24 = 7/24

questions.question: Mr. Tan gave 1/4 of his stamps to Ali and 2/5 of the remainder to Bob. What fraction of his original stamps did he have left?
questions.explanation:
Let total stamps = 1
To Ali: 1/4, Remainder: 3/4
To Bob: 2/5 × 3/4 = 6/20 = 3/10
Total given: 1/4 + 3/10 = 5/20 + 6/20 = 11/20
Left: 1 - 11/20 = 9/20

questions.question: In a class, 3/7 of the students are boys. If there are 12 more girls than boys, how many students are in the class?
questions.explanation:
Boys = 3/7, Girls = 4/7
Difference = 4/7 - 3/7 = 1/7
1/7 → 12 students
7/7 → 12 × 7 = 84 students
Wait, 84 is not an option! Let me check calculation:
If total = 42: Boys = 18, Girls = 24, Difference = 6 (not 12)
If total = 49: Boys = 21, Girls = 28, Difference = 7
If total = 56: Boys = 24, Girls = 32, Difference = 8
If total = 63: Boys = 27, Girls = 36, Difference = 9
So 1/7 = difference. If difference = 12, then total = 12 × 7 = 84
84 is not an option, so the question should say '6 more girls' for 42 total.
